title: What proportion of the following sample of ten measurements (1, 5, 9, 2, 6, and 3, 3, 4,5,2) lies within 2 standard deviations of the mean? - Quora

response.answer_text: Given the sample set of [math]\{ 1, 5, 9, 2, 6, 3, 3, 4, 5, 2 \} \tag*{}[/math] … we have [math]\sigma \approx 2.357[/math] and [math]\bar X = 4[/math]. So the interval of [math]2 \sigma[/math] we want to consider is [math]I_{2 \sigma} = [ \bar X - 2 \sigma, \bar X + 2\sigma] = [1.643, 6.357][/math]. We notice that the following fall into the interval. [math]\{ 2, 5, 6, 3, 3, 4, 5, 2 \} \tag*{}[/math] … which is [math]\frac{8}{10}[/math] of the set, meaning that [math]\frac{4}{5}[/math] is the proportion of the sample set that falls within [math]2 \sigma[/math] of [math]\bar X[/math].
